image.altText: Daniel Andrews makes a hand gesture at a press conference. He is outdoors

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Daniel Andrews not expected to appear at inquiry into Commonwealth Games cancellation — Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and his deputy Jacinta Allan are unlikely to appear before a parliamentary inquiry into the state government's decision to pull out of the Commonwealth Games. In an unprecedented move yesterday, the entire Crossbench voted with the Opposition to force a parliamentary inquiry into the debacle. But the upper house inquiry can't compel lower house MPs to appear — including the premier and former Commonwealth Games minister. Leader of the upper house, Jaclyn Symes, says she won't be encouraging them to appear at the public hearings. "This is an upper house inquiry. The Liberal Party knew that this was the rules of engagement when you have an upper house inquiry. "If they wanted to hear from lower house members they could've come to us and considered another forum."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Daniel Andrews not expected to appear at inquiry into Commonwealth Games cancellation

props.alt: A close up of Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews, speaking outside while wearing a suit and glasses

children.content: (AAP: James Ross)
Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and his deputy Jacinta Allan are unlikely to appear before a parliamentary inquiry into the state government's decision to pull out of the Commonwealth Games.
In an unprecedented move yesterday
, the entire Crossbench voted with the Opposition to force a parliamentary inquiry into the debacle.
But the upper house inquiry can't compel lower house MPs to appear
— including the premier and former Commonwealth Games minister.
Leader of the upper house, Jaclyn Symes, says she won't be encouraging them to appear at the public hearings.
"This is an upper house inquiry. The Liberal Party knew that this was the rules of engagement when you have an upper house inquiry.
"If they wanted to hear from lower house members they could've come to us and considered another forum."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian Federal Police has seized a property in the Perth suburb of Caversham and around $4.2 million held in two bank accounts, following an investigation into alleged family daycare fraud. The AFP says it alleges "the assets are owned by a family day care provider suspected to be claiming fraudulent child care subsidy payments". AFP Acting Commander Amelia McDonald says she wants to remind offenders that "crime doesn't pay". "In a time of rising cost of living pressures, it is crucial we target, identify and prosecute those breaking the law," she says. "Their actions drive up costs and hit the pockets of hardworking, honest Australians — and it will not be tolerated. "Furthermore, this is not a victimless crime and robs the Australian public of Government funds that support essential services such as health and education."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AFP seizes $4.2m and a Perth house over alleged daycare fraud

props.alt: Three men, one in a police jacket, stand out the front of a house while facing the building, next to a car

children.content: (Supplied: AFP)
Australian Federal Police has
seized a property in the Perth suburb of Caversham and around $4.2 million held in two bank accounts
, following an investigation into alleged family daycare fraud.
The AFP says it alleges "the assets are owned by a family day care provider suspected to be claiming fraudulent child care subsidy payments".
AFP Acting Commander Amelia McDonald says she wants to remind offenders that "crime doesn't pay".
"In a time of rising cost of living pressures, it is crucial we target, identify and prosecute those breaking the law," she says.
"Their actions drive up costs and hit the pockets of hardworking, honest Australians — and it will not be tolerated.
"Furthermore, this is not a victimless crime and robs the Australian public of Government funds that support essential services such as health and education."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand is expected to announce more money and resources for its defence force tomorrow, when Prime Minister Chris Hipkins' Labour government will release the country's first National Security Strategy. As AAP reports, an accompanying strategy report will outline where the government should focus its efforts, tackling emerging issues such as disinformation and economic security, supporting Pacific resilience and strengthening ties in the Indo-Pacific. New Zealand's government has already invested in replacing its Vietnam-era P-3 Orion surveillance planes with P-8 Poseidon aircraft, upgrading its C-130 Hercules cargo planes, and boosting salaries to improve retention. But its defence forces are still stretched thin. The review comes as concerns grow around national security, threats with geostrategic competition heating up and climate change causing more frequent and worse weather events. New Zealand's Defence Minister, Andrew Little, this year said that the country, which spends about 1 per cent of its GDP on defence, would need to make big investments as it faces these challenges.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand is expected to put more money towards defence in its first National Security Strategy

props.alt: A close up of the front windows of an armoured defence truck

children.content: (Supplied: New Zealand Defence Force)

New Zealand is expected to announce more money and resources for its defence force tomorrow, when Prime Minister Chris Hipkins' Labour government will release the country's first National Security Strategy.

As AAP reports, an accompanying strategy report will outline where the government should focus its efforts, tackling emerging issues such as disinformation and economic security, supporting Pacific resilience and strengthening ties in the Indo-Pacific.

New Zealand's government has already invested in replacing its Vietnam-era P-3 Orion surveillance planes with P-8 Poseidon aircraft, upgrading its C-130 Hercules cargo planes, and boosting salaries to improve retention.
But its defence forces are still stretched thin.
The review comes as
concerns grow around national security, threats with geostrategic competition heating up and climate change causing more frequent and worse weather events
New Zealand's Defence Minister, Andrew Little, this year said that the country, which spends about 1 per cent of its GDP on defence, would need to make big investments as it faces these challenges.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you were wondering why the Reserve Bank didn't hike interest rates on Tuesday — and many economists were — the detailed retail sales figures offer another strong clue. We had initial monthly retail figures on Friday last week, showing a 0.8% fall in June. But that was a 0.8% fall in the value of goods and services sold, and we all know that prices have generally been going up quite a bit, so the quantity of goods and services sold likely fell even further. Well, today the ABS has released data on the volume of retail sales for the June quarter — a key component of economic growth, as measured by Gross Domestic Product. The news is bleak. Retails sales volumes fell 0.5% in the June quarter, backing up a 0.8% plunge in the March quarter and a 0.4% fall in the three months to December 31 last year. All up, the bureau's head of retail statistics Ben Dorber says the annual number is the worst in more than three decades, if you exclude the pandemic lockdowns. "It's the first time since 2008 that retail sales volumes have recorded three consecutive quarterly falls," he noted in the report. "Retail sales volumes are down 1.4 per cent compared to the June quarter last year. "Outside of the pandemic period, this is the first time since 1991 that sales volumes have fallen compared to the previous year." What was happening in Australia in the early 90s? A very, very nasty recession mainly caused by surging interest rates. Sounds like a pretty good reason for the Reserve Bank to take a break on the rate hikes for now.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retail sales volumes fall over the year for the first time since 1991

children.content: If you were wondering why the Reserve Bank didn't hike interest rates on Tuesday — and many economists were — the detailed retail sales figures offer another strong clue.
We had initial monthly retail figures on Friday last week, showing a 0.8% fall in June. But that was a 0.8% fall in the
value
of goods and services sold, and we all know that prices have generally been going up quite a bit, so the
quantity
of goods and services sold likely fell even further.
Well, today the ABS has released data on the
volume
of retail sales for the June quarter — a key component of economic growth, as measured by Gross Domestic Product.
The news is bleak.
Retails sales volumes fell 0.5% in the June quarter
, backing up a 0.8% plunge in the March quarter and a 0.4% fall in the three months to December 31 last year.
All up, the bureau's head of retail statistics Ben Dorber says the annual number is the worst in more than three decades, if you exclude the pandemic lockdowns.
"It's the first time since 2008 that retail sales volumes have recorded three consecutive quarterly falls," he noted in the report.
"Retail sales volumes are down 1.4 per cent compared to the June quarter last year.
"Outside of the pandemic period, this is the first time since 1991 that sales volumes have fallen compared to the previous year."
What was happening in Australia in the early 90s? A very, very nasty recession mainly caused by surging interest rates.
Sounds like a pretty good reason for the Reserve Bank to take a break on the rate hikes for now.
